data.source: Secondary analysis of the ELEMENT study (Assessment of Reading and Mathematics Development) using standardized tests and student/parent questionnaires from public elementary schools in Berlin, Germany.
data.wave_or_subset: Sixth grade elementary school sample (Grade 6) from a representative Berlin cohort.
data.sample_size: 2835 students nested in 134 classes (final analytic sample); original Grade 6 sample N=2946.
data.notes: Bilingual group identification based on home language reported by parents (student report used if parent data missing); 111 students lacked language information. Multiple imputation (5 datasets) addressed missing data, largely due to lower parent response rates (~60%) and attrition between grades (7%). Tests scaled with 1-parameter IRT in ACER ConQuest; English and German scores reported as WLEs (English scaled to M=100, SD=20). Analyses accounted for class-level clustering (type=complex).

method.description: The study conducted secondary analyses of ELEMENT Grade 6 data to examine whether speaking a minority language at home (bilingualism) relates to English-as-foreign-language achievement, controlling for background factors and considering German (instructional language) proficiency. Bilingual status and specific bilingual language groups were derived from reported home language. English achievement was measured via a Cloze test scaled with IRT (WLE). Multiple regression models tested associations with controls for cognitive ability, age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, cultural capital (books at home), and German reading proficiency. Missing data were handled via multiple imputation; clustering by classroom was accounted for.
steps: Load ELEMENT Grade 6 dataset for Berlin public elementary schools.
Determine language groups using parent-reported home language (use student report if parent data missing); exclude cases with no language information.

Define groups: German monolingual (n=1896); bilingual overall (n=939) further split into Arabic-German (n=105), Chinese-German (n=110), Polish-German (n=57), Turkish-German (n=383), and Other bilingual (n=284).
Use provided IRT-scaled English Cloze test WLE scores (M=100, SD=20) as the outcome.

As controls, assemble general cognitive ability (CFT 4-12R verbal and figural analogies from Grade 4), age, gender, HISEI (highest parental ISEI), parental education (5-point scale), cultural capital (books at home, 4-point scale), and German reading proficiency (IRT-scaled).
Address missingness via multiple imputation (5 datasets) based on a background model including individual- and classroom-level factors; pool estimates.
Compute descriptive statistics with Bonferroni-adjusted comparisons.

Fit linear regression models: (a) bilingual vs monolingual, without and with controls; (b) bilingual subgroups by German proficiency level vs monolingual, without and with controls; (c) language-group models (Arabic-, Chinese-, Polish-, Turkish-German, and Other bilingual vs monolingual) adding controls in stages and finally including German reading proficiency.
Account for classroom clustering (type=complex) and pool across imputations; report coefficients and explained variance.
method.models: Multiple linear regression with cluster-robust adjustments (type=complex) and pooled multiple imputation; test scaling via 1-parameter IRT (Rasch) with WLE person estimates.
method.outcome_variable: English language achievement (Cloze test WLE, scaled M=100, SD=20) in Grade 6.
method.independent_variables: Primary exposures: bilingual status (bilingual vs monolingual), bilingual language group (Arabic-German, Chinese-German, Polish-German, Turkish-German, Other bilingual), bilingual groups by German proficiency levels; German reading proficiency included as a key predictor/moderator.
method.control_variables: General cognitive abilities (CFT 4-12R verbal and figural analogies), age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, cultural capital (books at home), and in some models German reading proficiency.
method.tools_software: ACER ConQuest for IRT scaling; Mplus 5.21 for multiple regression with multiple imputation (option type=imputation) and clustering (type=complex).

results.summary: Unadjusted, bilingual students scored lower than monolinguals in English. After controlling for cognitive abilities, age, gender, socio-economic status, parental education, and cultural capital, bilingual status was positively associated with English achievement. German (instructional language) proficiency was a strong predictor of English outcomes; bilingual students with stronger German skills tended to outperform monolinguals, while those with weaker German did not. Advantages varied by language group: controlling for background factors, Chinese-German, Polish-German, and Other bilingual groups had significant advantages over monolinguals; Turkish-German showed a small, non-significant advantage; Arabic-German showed no advantage. When additionally controlling for German reading proficiency, all bilingual groups except Arabic-German had significant advantages. Models explained up to 46% of variance when German proficiency was included.
